additionalTextInformation.text:
Looks like 'Master H B with Griffon's Head'
[comment by cda user Paul Jeromack, 27 Jan. 2012]

pageContext.description:
The Allegory of Love is personified as mother's love in the form of a woman, who holds a naked infant in her arms and embraces another child with her left arm. 
[Herrschaft, cda 2015]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 51.5 x 38 (plus an additional  0.5 cm, which is hidden by the grooved frame) x 1.2 cm
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

metadata.title: Allegory of Love

pageContext.provenance:
- 1826 Gotha, Art Cabinet, Friedenstein castle, Picture Gallery
- 1856 Ducal Art and Antiquities Collection, Coburg (Herzogliche Kunst- und Altertümersammlung der Veste Coburg (HKA))
- 1919 Kunstsammlungen der Veste Coburg (KVC) 
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
Support:
- the planks are warped and loose 
- the reverse exhibits toolmarks from the thinning process. The panel was thinned and chamfered along the edges to slide it into the grooved frame. Otherwise the surface is rather rough. Two paper strips were attached along the join between planks II and III. The reverse has been stained a reddish-brown 
Paint layers:
- various tiny point retouches 
- losses along the edges of the panel 
- the artist's insignia is located beneath a thick varnish layer 
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

restorationSurveys.remarks:
Conservation treatment  (with a detailed condition report)
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

Conservation treatment (with a detailed treatment report)
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

tests.text:
Identification of wood species: lime wood

[Klein report, 03.03.2016]

- lime wood
- four vertically aligned and butt-joined planks. Plank I: 8.0 cm; plank II: 14 cm; plank III: 12 cm; plank IV: 4 cm
- saw marks are visible along the joins between planks I/II and III/IV
- executed in a fluid medium with a broad brush, deviates considerably from the final painted version

- probably original frame 
- fluted profile with two different finishes one on top of the other; the lower one is probably original 
[Cat. Coburg 2018, 110]

pageContext.signature:
Artist's insignia bottom right, above the remains of an old label: winged serpent and dated '1509' (the date is barely visible today)
[Kunstsammlungen der Veste Coburg, revised 2010]
